Literature Review: Epigenetic regulation plays a crucial role in plant development, allowing plants to adapt to environmental changes and respond to stress. Epigenetic modifications, such as histone modifications and DNA methylation, provide an additional layer of regulation beyond genetically encoded factors. In this review, we discuss the establishment, maintenance, and removal of epigenetic modifications during plant development and their functional consequences. We also explore the concept of epigenetic memory and its relationship with epigenetic inheritance between generations. Our discussion is supported by a comprehensive review of the literature, including studies on histone modifications, DNA methylation, and transposable element regulation in plants under different environmental conditions.
